EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along most of the Ohio River, with pockets of only minor flooding. A heavy rainfall event on March 3 was followed by a major winter storm on March 4 into early March 5. Two more heavy rainfall events occurred in quick succession. On the 9th and 10th, one to two inches of rain fell, followed by two to four more inches on the 13th and 14th. The combined effect of all these rain and snow events was a prolonged flooding event on the Ohio River. Since the precipitation was spread out over a 10-day period, the magnitude of the flooding was generally moderate instead of major.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred on the Ohio River. At the Newburgh river gage, the river crested at 48.07 feet on the 17th. Flood stage is 38 feet. Floodwaters approached or covered Indiana Route 66 about one mile downriver from the Newburgh dam. Highway 662 was flooded near the old lock and dam. Some low-lying agricultural land was flooded. The crest of 48.07 feet was the tenth highest on record for Newburgh, and it was a foot below the April, 2011 flood crest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along most of the Ohio River, with pockets of only minor flooding. A heavy rainfall event on March 3 was followed by a major winter storm on March 4 into early March 5. Two more heavy rainfall events occurred in quick succession. On the 9th and 10th, one to two inches of rain fell, followed by two to four more inches on the 13th and 14th. The combined effect of all these rain and snow events was a prolonged flooding event on the Ohio River. Since the precipitation was spread out over a 10-day period, the magnitude of the flooding was generally moderate instead of major.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred on the Ohio River. At the Evansville river gage, the river crested at 45.21 feet on the 18th. Flood stage is 42 feet. About 20 secondary roads were flooded in bottomland areas near the river. They were mostly farm roads flooded near the river, outside the Evansville city limits. Most of the flooded roads were south of Interstate 164 in the southeast part of the county and in lowland areas in the southwest part of the county. One motorist drowned after disregarding barricades and driving down a flooded road. A passenger in the vehicle was able to roll down a window and escape from the pickup truck. A police officer arrived, threw a rope to the passenger, and pulled her to safety. The driver of the truck was located underwater by the dive team of the Evansville Fire Department. CPR was administered to the driver, who was rushed to a local hospital. The passenger was treated and released from the hospital. The driver died at the hospital. The estimated water level at the scene of the drowning was estimated to be at least 6 or 7 feet. Floodwaters backed up into Pigeon Creek, forcing that creek well out of its banks. The crest of 45.21 feet was about a foot-and-a-half below the crest of the April, 2011 flood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure tracking east through the northern Ohio Valley brought a prolonged period of moderate to heavy snow to the region February 1st into early February 2nd. Snowfall totals generally ranged between 12 and 17 inches north of the US 24 corridor, with lesser amounts to the south as rain mixed in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed during the late evening hours of January 31st and became heavy at times February 1st into early February 2nd. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 11 and 16 inches, heaviest across northern portions of the county. Wind gusts of 20 to 30 mph, combined with the falling snow, created reduced visibilities and blowing snow. Numerous events were cancelled across the region, along with reports of slide-offs and accidents due to snow covered and slick roads. There were also reports of road closures in rural areas as unplowed roads became impassible. The heavy, wet, nature of the snow also led to sporadic power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system brought flooding rains to southern Indiana, followed quickly by very heavy snow. The upper level pattern featured a positively tilted upper low across the desert southwest on the 3nd of March. A tight baroclinic zone stretched northeastward through southern Indiana. Strong southwesterly flow at lower levels brought rich moisture along this nearly stationary boundary. Initially, during the evening hours on the 3nd, rain developed along this boundary and gradually overspread all of southern Indiana and central Kentucky. Steady rain continued through the late afternoon on the 4th. One to two inches of rain fell across southern Indiana before precipitation changed into snow during the mid afternoon hours. Minor areal flooding developed across southern Indiana with several roads and low water crossings closed. ||Rain quickly changed to snow as a cold front moved south into Kentucky. Heavy snow fell from mid afternoon on the 4th through the early morning hours of the next day. Snowfall amounts ranged from around 5 inches in northern sections of Dubois, Orange, and Jefferson Counties to just under one foot along the Ohio River southwest of Louisville. This snow fell at a very fast rate, with very low visibilities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of snow was measured in Corydon.  Up to 10 inches fell across the southern portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure brought snow to central Indiana, starting the evening of February 28th and continuing into March 1st. Parts of central Indiana received up to 11 to 12.5 inches of snow during the event. The 11 inches of snow on the ground at Indianapolis on March 1st was the most snow on the ground so late in the year since February 29th, 1984, which also had 11 inches. Some counties north of the warned area accumulated 6 inches of snow after 12 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall began around 7:00 PM EST on February 28th. Snowfall amounts of 7 to 12.5 inches were reported from in and around the Indianapolis area before ending around 3:00 PM EST on March 1st.  No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along most of the Ohio River, with pockets of only minor flooding. A heavy rainfall event on March 3 was followed by a major winter storm on March 4 into early March 5. Two more heavy rainfall events occurred in quick succession. On the 9th and 10th, one to two inches of rain fell, followed by two to four more inches on the 13th and 14th. The combined effect of all these rain and snow events was a prolonged flooding event on the Ohio River. Since the precipitation was spread out over a 10-day period, the magnitude of the flooding was generally moderate instead of major.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred on the Ohio River. At the Mount Vernon river gage, the river crested at 46.40 feet on the 19th. Flood stage is 35 feet. Large portions of Point Township in Posey County were flooded. Farmland and some main roads were flooded in places southwest and west of Mt. Vernon. Spring planting was not yet underway, so crop losses were negligible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State officials reported that several roads were closed due to high water flowing over them. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain fell on top of very saturated ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving across the southern U.S. brought accumulating snow to the southern half of central Indiana on February 16th. Some areas received around 8 inches of snow. Higher amounts were received in Kentucky with this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5.5 inches was observed in Crane. Roads were reported to be slick. Since the 16th was Presidents' Day, schools were not in session. Some schools had delays the following day. No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State officials reported high water flowing over numerous roads in the county. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell, the highest amounts across the northern portions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado first touched down just east of Lake Celina where one tree was uprooted and others were snapped.  The tornado then continued east across IN-37 where it uprooted and snapped several dozen trees along Old IN-37.  The damage continued east towards Ottoman Road where a carport was destroyed, along with additional trees that were snapped and uprooted.  From there, the tornado took a jog to the northeast across Orchid and St. Croix Roads where it caused substantial tree damage, uprooting and/or snapping trunks 15-20 feet high on approximately 100 trees.  The tornado then lifted just east of Saint Croix Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported high water swiftly flowing over numerous streets in town. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported water running over Highway 145 south of Birdseye.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported numerous stalled and stranded vehicles across Harrison County. Several cars were stuck in water on Route 11 and Route 111.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media shared image of flooding of Indian Creek near the city of Corydon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured a 56 knot wind gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported trees down around the Jasper area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front which pushed across the region during the morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 68 mph instantaneous gust was recorded on a personal weather station. The average gust was 48 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of thunderstorms moved eastward into southwest Indiana during the late evening hours. At the surface, a low pressure center over northwest Missouri deepened northeastward into southern Wisconsin. A cold front trailing south-southwest from the low strengthened and accelerated east across the Mid-Mississippi Valley and Ozarks to the Lower Ohio Valley. At mid levels, the storms were supported by a weak lead disturbance that crossed the Ozarks, headed northeast to the Ohio Valley. Ample west-southwesterly deep-layer wind shear (from 40 to 45 knots) existed for sustained severe storms. The degree of low-level forcing along the front resulted in an extensive, broken squall line with embedded bowing structures. A bowing structure moved through the Evansville airport area, producing a corridor of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds estimated near 70 mph caused damage at the Evansville Regional Airport. The three-mile long damage area began about two miles west of the airport and ended on the east side of the airport. The damage area was up to two-thirds of a mile wide. West of the airport, several sections of yard fencing and numerous tree limbs and small trees were blown down. The end roof section of a vinyl roof building was blown off. The covering of a nearby sign board was blown partially off. At the Evansville airport, a tarmac loading ramp was blown into the side of a commercial aircraft. The aircraft was dented, and the flight was cancelled. A utility light pole was blown over at the airport. A wind gust to 67 mph was measured by the automated observing system at the Evansville Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated a wind gust to 70 mph in Lamar. In Chrisney, tree branches were broken by winds estimated near 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
Thunderstorms developed along a northward moving warm front, with a few producing marginally severe hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large tree limbs were down. A trained spotter measured a wind gust to 67 mph before the wind equipment was ripped off its pole.

A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down just west of U.S. Highway 41 and then moved south of due east. Power poles were broken along U.S. Highway 41. At least three farm machinery sheds and garages were destroyed. Three grain bins were destroyed. Numerous other small structures were overturned or destroyed. One home had major structural damage, including an exterior wall pushed outward. The exterior wall was on the end of the house with an attached garage. Dozens of homes lost shingles or gutters. Many dozens of trees were uprooted or snapped. A semi was overturned at the Interstate 164 junction with State Route 57. Peak winds were estimated near 110 mph. The average path width was 325 yards. The majority of damage occurred in Vanderburgh County. This tornado continued into Warrick County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado continued from Vanderburgh County. The majority of the damage with this tornado occurred in Vanderburgh County. Most of the damage path in Warrick County was through rural areas. A few homes lost shingles and gutters.  Dozens of trees were uprooted or snapped. The average path width was 325 yards. Peak winds were estimated near 110 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum winds were estimated near 95 mph. One barn was destroyed, and several other barns sustained major roof damage. A garage lost its roof. Several trees were blown down. The funnel was sighted from Tennyson by a trained spotter.

The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado began along the eastern edge of Warrick County. Peak winds were estimated near 95 mph. Some trees were damaged. Most of the damage occurred during the Spencer County portion of the track. This tornado continued into Spencer County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was covering the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.

Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A live, 18-inch diameter tree branch was downed on State Road 234 due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A soaking rain brought an average of just under 2 inches to southern Indiana during the 13th and 14th of March. Local streams and rivers, already quite high due to previous heavy rains and snow melt went into flood over the subsequent several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall over the previous 2 weeks brought the Ohio River at Clifty Creek into minor flood. The river crested at 453.1 feet on the morning of March 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along the Patoka River. At the river gage near Princeton, the river crested at 22.57 feet on the 10th. Flood stage is 18 feet. Many county roads were closed in the vicinity of the river. The flooding affected areas of farmland. Seasonal camping trailers closest to the river were flooded or moved to higher ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred on the White River. Bottomland woods and fields were flooded. High water affected any residents that were in river cabins. A few streets were submerged. Oil stripped fields were inundated. Flood gates were installed at Hazleton. Floodwaters covered the Hazleton softball field. Floodwaters covered low farmland, but the land was dormant since it was not agricultural season.

A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado continued from Warrick County. Numerous trees and limbs were blown down, including some large trees that were snapped or uprooted. Peak winds were estimated near 95 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Transportation officials reported that downed trees had to be removed from roadways across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog, with visibilities reduced to as low as 20 feet, created hazardous driving conditions during the morning hours of March 11th. The fog was partially blamed for a 22 car accident that killed 2 people on I-65 in White County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog played havoc from the late evening hours of March 10th to shortly after sunrise on March 11th, contributing to several accidents and numerous school closings. This dense fog was a factor in 2 separate accidents, the first occurring around 10 pm local time on Interstate 65 near mile marker 188, with a second in the early morning hours of the 11th. A car and semi collided, resulting in the death of a passenger in the car. Other vehicles became involved in the accident with additional injuries reported. A second accident occurred in the same area, likely due to traffic stopping for the first accident, causing yet another fatality as well as several injuries.

After a very wet and active weather pattern in March, little relief was observed in April across much of the lower Great Lakes and Ohio Valley. Repeated rounds of heavy rain, thunderstorms and occasional severe weather occurred in the Ohio River basin across Indiana, northern Kentucky and portions of Ohio. This resulted in a prolonged period of high water and flooding on the Ohio River, especially from Cannelton to Tell City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain both locally and well upstream brought the Ohio River at Cannelton to flood. The river crested at 42.3 feet on April 18th, then fell below flood stage on April 20th.

Following the heavy snow, heavy rain and subsequent snow melt of March 4-5, additional rainfall March 7 - 11 continued minor river flooding across southern Indiana. This resulted in the Ohio River to rise above flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An unusually wet period with repeated rounds of heavy rain brought the Ohio River at Tell City into a long duration flood. The river went above flood stage March 7th, crested on March 17th and then fell below flood stage March 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy snowfall was pushing southeast through central Indiana on the afternoon of the 4th of February. A 79-year-old Rossville man left a store in Clinton County and it is thought that he hit a patch of heavier snowfall, left the road on Indiana 39/U.S. Highway 421, traveled down the berm, and entered Wildcat Creek where he made it out of his truck but drowned before reaching the creek's bank.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Just north of Clinton County Road 200 North, a 79-year-old Rossville man and his truck left the east side of the road, traveled down the berm, and entered the creek. The man made it out of the truck, but was unable to get to the bank.||He had left home about 2 p.m. on February 4th to run to a store in Frankfort. Clinton County sheriff???s investigators said someone remembered seeing the man in a store about 3:15 p.m. That was about the time the snow squall started blowing through the area.||???Everything is leaning to a motor vehicle crash,??? the Clinton County sheriff said.||The snow was so heavy and visibility was so poor in that area on February 4th that a construction crew working north of the creek pulled their trucks and equipment off the road to avoid any mishaps. It is sometime during this snow squall that the Rossville man likely was traveling north on Indiana 39/U.S. Highway 421.||This information was obtained from the Lafayette Journal and Courier online.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were down on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of thunderstorms moved eastward into southwest Indiana during the late evening hours. At the surface, a low pressure center over northwest Missouri deepened northeastward into southern Wisconsin. A cold front trailing south-southwest from the low strengthened and accelerated east across the Mid-Mississippi Valley and Ozarks to the Lower Ohio Valley. At mid levels, the storms were supported by a weak lead disturbance that crossed the Ozarks, headed northeast to the Ohio Valley. Ample west-southwesterly deep-layer wind shear (from 40 to 45 knots) existed for sustained severe storms. The degree of low-level forcing along the front resulted in an extensive, broken squall line with embedded bowing structures. A bowing structure moved through the Evansville airport area, producing a corridor of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust was measured to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure brought snow to central Indiana, starting the evening of February 28th and continuing into March 1st. Parts of central Indiana received up to 11 to 12.5 inches of snow during the event. The 11 inches of snow on the ground at Indianapolis on March 1st was the most snow on the ground so late in the year since February 29th, 1984, which also had 11 inches. Some counties north of the warned area accumulated 6 inches of snow after 12 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall began around 5:00 PM EST on February 28th. Snowfall amounts of 7 inches were reported in and around the Terre Haute area before ending around 3:00 PM EST on March 1st.  No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another subtle weather disturbance pushed through the Ohio Valley on the afternoon and evening of April 8th.  This disturbance interacted with a very moist and unstable airmass, characterized by temperatures in the upper 70s and 80s.  Supercell thunderstorms developed across parts of the area, producing hail across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported hail up to the size of pennys.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media relayed that wind gusts estimated to be between 65 and 70 mph occurred.

Dozens of trees were uprooted. Many tree limbs were blown down. The microburst was about one mile wide on average.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported water over State Route 64 near Huntingburg. Between 4 and 5 inches of rain were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Wabash River. Low-lying fields and woodlands near the river were inundated. Some stripper oil wells began to flood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River. There was considerable flooding of bottomland woods and fields. A number of county roads were flooded, including  |750N, 600N, and 1000E east of State Route 57. Flooded roads west of State Route  57 included 250W, 400W, 675N, 700N, 1000W, 900W, 700W, and 775W. Flooding affected low agricultural lands and low oil fields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Wabash River. A few local river roads were closed by high water. All oil field production ceased with the exception of pumping units on substructures. Farmers moved livestock to higher ground. Many river cabins became inaccessible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the morning of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, with singular observations of damaging winds and flash flooding.

A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the morning of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, with singular observations of damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail sizes ranged from one quarter of an inch to one inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some minor road flooding was occurring due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding, with a depth of up to one foot, occurred in the northeast part of Rushville due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood waters were curb high, possibly deeper under overpasses, due to thunderstorm heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.

An area of low pressure brought snow to central Indiana, starting the evening of February 28th and continuing into March 1st. Parts of central Indiana received up to 11 to 12.5 inches of snow during the event. The 11 inches of snow on the ground at Indianapolis on March 1st was the most snow on the ground so late in the year since February 29th, 1984, which also had 11 inches. Some counties north of the warned area accumulated 6 inches of snow after 12 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall began around 5:00 PM EST on February 28th. Snowfall amounts of 7 to 7.5 inches were reported in the Perrysville area before ending around 2:00 PM EST on March 1st.  No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at the White county airport recorded a 64 mph wind gust as a severe thunderstorm moved through.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low was situated over the Great Lakes region. A disturbance moved through the area, helping kick off convection in the early afternoon near the surface-based stationary front. High precipitable waters and limited bulk shear created a good setup for wet microbursts, with some storms producing locally significant wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported eight to twelve inch tree limbs down. A power pole was snapped in half in the area as well.

Scattered strong to severe storms developed on the afternoon and evening of the 4th focused over the eastern half of central Indiana. A measured 70 mph wind gust brought trees and limbs down near Greenfield, and penny to nickel size hail was reported from the eastern Indianapolis suburbs east into Hancock County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damaging thunderstorm winds of an estimated 70 mph was observed in this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved towards northern Illinois during the evening hours, causing thunderstorms to develop in the afternoon and evening hours across northern Illinois and northwest Indiana.  A moist environment helped to produce heavy rainfall across portions of northern Illinois. A brief tornado occurred across the Frankfort-Monee area.  As the storm moved over northwest Indiana hail and wind damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large hail reported across southern parts of Benton County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered strong to severe storms developed on the afternoon and evening of the 4th focused over the eastern half of central Indiana. A measured 70 mph wind gust brought trees and limbs down near Greenfield, and penny to nickel size hail was reported from the eastern Indianapolis suburbs east into Hancock County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and/or utility lines were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This was one of multiple locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust was observed in this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe storms moved into the northern Wabash valley late on the evening of the 18th before weakening, producing penny size hail and wind gusts up to 80 mph over parts of Tippecanoe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was reported in Otterbein just inside Tippecanoe County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe storms moved into the northern Wabash valley late on the evening of the 18th before weakening, producing penny size hail and wind gusts up to 80 mph over parts of Tippecanoe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured thunderstorm wind gust of 80 mph was observed in this location. Sustained winds were measured at 59 mph at the intersection of State Route 25 North and County Road 900 North.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe storms moved into the northern Wabash valley late on the evening of the 18th before weakening, producing penny size hail and wind gusts up to 80 mph over parts of Tippecanoe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This event occurred at Highway 52 and Piermont Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grain silo was downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to widely scattered thunderstorms moved across northeast Illinois and into northwest Indiana during the late afternoon and evening hours.
Isolated to widely scattered thunderstorms moved across northeast Illinois and into northwest Indiana during the late afternoon and evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail persisted several minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to widely scattered thunderstorms moved across northeast Illinois and into northwest Indiana during the late afternoon and evening hours.

A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county Emergency Manager reported 1.75 inch diameter hail in Alton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported silver dollar size hail in Corydon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms pushed northeast into west-central and southwest Indiana during the evening hours of May the 15th. These storms produced severe winds as they moved northeast into southwest and central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observing station at the Terre Haute Airport measured a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced localized 60 to 70 mph wind damage in Orange County, Indiana. Dime-sized hail was reported with the storm as it moved east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was snapped and fell over as reported by the public. It was confirmed by a social media picture relayed by a member of broadcast media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced localized 60 to 70 mph wind damage in Orange County, Indiana. Dime-sized hail was reported with the storm as it moved east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported wind damage to a barn near County Road 200N and 50E.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced localized 60 to 70 mph wind damage in Orange County, Indiana. Dime-sized hail was reported with the storm as it moved east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of dime size hail in Paoli.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms pushed northeast into west-central and southwest Indiana during the evening hours of May the 15th. These storms produced severe winds as they moved northeast into southwest and central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down at 226th Street and State Route 38 due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced localized 60 to 70 mph wind damage in Orange County, Indiana. Dime-sized hail was reported with the storm as it moved east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed to the NWS a public video of dime size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of a complex of thunderstorms that moved through Illinois entered a moderately unstable and sheared environment across northern Indiana. Precipitable water values were running high, allowing for an increased threat of wet microbursts. Several of these occurred, producing localized damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a measured wind gust of 60 mph as well as a old bank barn collapsing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of a complex of thunderstorms that moved through Illinois entered a moderately unstable and sheared environment across northern Indiana. Precipitable water values were running high, allowing for an increased threat of wet microbursts. Several of these occurred, producing localized damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a tree snapped at the base and fell onto a power line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a surface low over the upper Mississippi River valley and strong southerly flow from the Gulf to the Great Lakes, a weak trough and associated frontal boundary moved into a low CAPE, high shear environment. This favored development of several clusters of thunderstorms. The stronger convection merged into small, fast moving bow segments that produced sporadic wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a few trees were blown down near State Road 26 between County Roads 700 and 800 East. Roof panels of a barn were also damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported quarter size hail at the intersection of County Road 125 North and 1000 East.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.

Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated wind gusts to 60 mph. Pea size hail was also observed with the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a large tree was blown down across Lincoln Blvd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated wind gusts to 60 mph at the intersection of County Road 125 North and 1000 East.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.

After a morning complex of non-severe storms on June 7th, redeveloping storms in the early afternoon intensified just south of I-80 and slowly evolved southeastward through the night, producing heavy rainfall rates and at times severe straight-line winds.  Widespread rainfall of one and a half to four inches, with isolated totals higher fell across areas south of I-80. This produced flooding and flash flooding. Scattered reports of roads closed during Sunday mid-afternoon through evening were  received.  There were a couple reports of water rescues and stranded vehicles. The highest rainfall reports were 4.95 inches near Kouts, IN and 4.07 inches near Hebron, IN, both from CoCoRaHS volunteer observers.  There was video confirmation of two brief tornadoes in northern Jasper County, a few miles from the community of De Motte.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-0 tornado briefly touched down northwest of De Motte and was captured on video by trained spotters.  No damage occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several Roads in Hebron were closed due to flooding and at least on rescue had to be performed for a vehicle trapped in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated damaging wind gusts occurred with bands of northeastward moving thunderstorms. Weak to moderate instability and deep, unidirectional southwesterly flow aloft helped to maintain the storms. A 500 mb shortwave trough over the Ozarks moved northeast to the vicinity of the Ohio and Mississippi River confluence by mid-afternoon. A weak surface low pressure center moved northeast from southeast Missouri into south central Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small child was killed when a tree limb landed on her. The incident occurred at an outdoor family reunion. The tree limb fell about 50 feet, striking a father and his daughter. The father was hospitalized with a broken neck and other injuries. The young girl died in the hospital a couple of days later. There were a couple of other downed tree limbs in the immediate area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were flooded in Cedar Lake and at least one pickup truck was half submerged on the flooded roads.  An observer reported 3.94 inches of rainfall in Cedar Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operator reported this observation to Emergency Management. Visibility was near zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Anderson Fire Department worked two water rescues in the area of 8th Street and Raible Avenue due to flash flooding caused by heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms pushed northeast into west-central and southwest Indiana during the evening hours of May the 15th. These storms produced severe winds as they moved northeast into southwest and central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust was observed at the Channel 2 location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms pushed northeast into west-central and southwest Indiana during the evening hours of May the 15th. These storms produced severe winds as they moved northeast into southwest and central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small tree limbs were reported down in this location due to damaging thunderstorm wind gust estimated at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was uprooted and damage occurred to an exterior porch addition.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Upper level energy moved into the region, helping initiate convection north of a decaying mesoscale convective system across central and southern Illinois. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a empty semi trailer was blown off the road by high winds on Interstate 69, near mile marker 334. The driver sustained minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Upper level energy moved into the region, helping initiate convection north of a decaying mesoscale convective system across central and southern Illinois. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a tree and power line down across the road at Division Road and County Road 200 West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Upper level energy moved into the region, helping initiate convection north of a decaying mesoscale convective system across central and southern Illinois. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported trees and power lines down on the east side of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Upper level energy moved into the region, helping initiate convection north of a decaying mesoscale convective system across central and southern Illinois. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported at least one four to five inch diameter tree limb down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced torrential rain across portions of northwest Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads were closed near the Kankakee River due to renewed rises and the river coming out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved into northwestern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported near 400 South and 500 West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed to the NWS that multiple vehicles were stranded in high water on Vincennes Street in New Albany.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Kentucky state official indicated that because of torrential rainfall, there was high water flowing over Route 211. The report also indicated that other locations around town were experiencing high water and flooding issues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed along a frontal boundary over northwest Indiana during the late afternoon hours of May the 18th. As these storms pushed east-southeast into central Indiana during the early evening, one moved over Tipton County causing some wind damage in the Sharpsville area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three trees were reported down due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. Power outages were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Parkwood subdivision in Clarksville had water covered roadways due to torrential downpours from slow moving thunderstorms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An Indiana state official reported that fallen trees due to severe thunderstorm winds had to be removed from roads on 2 Mile Lane and Corydon Pike.

Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Harrison County emergency manager reported that severe thunderstorm winds brought down power lines on State Road 62 approximately 1/2 mile east of Corydon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A barn and two houses sustained roof damage near the intersection of County Roads 600 West and 100 South due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.  Also, three trees were downed...including one on a car.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Beginning on the 7th, numerous weather systems brought seemingly unending rains and at times torrential downpours to various portions of the state. The first heavy rains of the month occurred in portions of east central Illinois in addition to west central and northwest Indiana.  Rainfall of 2 to nearly 6 inches on the 7th caused flooding across portions of Warren, Fountain, and Vermillion counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch said County Road 900 West was closed between County Roads 825 South and 950 South due to high water from heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a warm, humid air mass an approaching cold front to the northwest of the area produced scattered strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Perry County emergency manager reported 1 inch hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a warm, humid air mass an approaching cold front to the northwest of the area produced scattered strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Perry County emergency manager reported numerous trees down with damage to vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large limbs were downed across central Franklin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An outdoor barn and storage facility were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were downed in the vicinity of West County Road 300N and North County Road 150W.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two semi trailers were blown into the median of I-70 near the State Route 1 interchange.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Upper level energy moved into the region, helping initiate convection north of a decaying mesoscale convective system across central and southern Illinois. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported hail along US 31 between Rochester and Deedsville, causing traffic to come to a halt for a a period.

Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed to the NWS a report of a barn roof partially blown off due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnants of Tropical Storm Bill brought a very moist and tropical air mass to the lower Ohio Valley and combined with very warm temperatures, several rounds of strong to severe thunderstorms developed between June 18th and 20th. Damaging winds, hail, and flash flooding were the primary hazards during this period. However, one stronger thunderstorm on the spiral band of TS Bill produced a short lived EF-0 tornado a few miles northwest of Tell City, Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An Indiana state official reported to the NWS that water was covering Wickcliffe Road near the Dearview campground. Due to the high water, the road was impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over County Road 100 West, south of State Road 32, due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The roof of a barn was tossed across a roadway and multiple trees were down near the intersection of Owens Farm Road and County Road 60 West due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
