The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree limb fell on a power line on Busseron Street due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A three inch diameter tree limb was snapped due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts. This was reported by BAM Chase.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 30-inch diameter tree was blown over onto part of a fence near the intersection of Stop 11 and Shelbyville Roads due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into a weakly unstable environment, producing scattered thunderstorms. Pockets of strong wind aloft mixed down but struggled to reach severe levels. One storm took on super-cellular characteristics in the Fort Wayne area, but produced little more than very heavy rain and marginally severe hail.

A cold front moved into a weakly unstable environment, producing scattered thunderstorms. Pockets of strong wind aloft mixed down but struggled to reach severe levels. One storm took on super-cellular characteristics in the Fort Wayne area, but produced little more than very heavy rain and marginally severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported dime size hail in the Pleasant Mills area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Upper level energy moved into the region, helping initiate convection north of a decaying mesoscale convective system across central and southern Illinois. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a empty semi trailer was blown off the road by high winds on Interstate 69, near mile marker 334. The driver sustained minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported over a dozen trees and tree limbs were blown down along the Winona Lake Cycling and Walking trails.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of a complex of thunderstorms that moved through Illinois entered a moderately unstable and sheared environment across northern Indiana. Precipitable water values were running high, allowing for an increased threat of wet microbursts. Several of these occurred, producing localized damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported several trees and tree limbs down in Bourbon. A few of these fell onto homes and power lines. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An employee with Winzerwald Winery reported golf ball sized hail. Patio furniture on the property also was blown around due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnants of Tropical Storm Bill brought a very moist and tropical air mass to the lower Ohio Valley and combined with very warm temperatures, several rounds of strong to severe thunderstorms developed between June 18th and 20th. Damaging winds, hail, and flash flooding were the primary hazards during this period. However, one stronger thunderstorm on the spiral band of TS Bill produced a short lived EF-0 tornado a few miles northwest of Tell City, Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS storm survey team located a small tornado roughly 1 mile east-northeast of Troy. The damage was confined to an area approximately 1/3 of a mile long and 50 yards wide. There was substantial soft and hardwood tree damage east of the industrial park, in a heavily forested area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last widespread rains of the month were the result of a developing low pressure area that moved through the state on the 26th and early on the 27th. Numerous flooding problems developed quickly across mainly northern sections of central Indiana. People were rescued from cars and homes were flooded in the Muncie area and other areas of east central Indiana. Much of the state along and north of Interstate 70 received 2 to 5 inches of rain. Two individuals perished near Noblesville when their automobile hit water on a road and crashed into a telephone pole.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: RTV6 reported that a Noblesville man and a teenage girl were killed in a one-car crash after encountering flooding on a Hamilton County road early Saturday morning. The man, 39, was driving with three juveniles on Promise Road north of 181st Street just before 12:30 AM EDT. The high water caused his car to go off the road and strike a mailbox and utility pole, officials with the Hamilton County Sheriff???s Office said. He was taken to Riverview Hospital where he died of his injuries. One of the passengers was a 16-year-old girl who was in the back seat of the car. She also died of her injuries. The other two juvenile passengers were taken to a Fishers hospital with minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated damaging wind gusts occurred with bands of northeastward moving thunderstorms. Weak to moderate instability and deep, unidirectional southwesterly flow aloft helped to maintain the storms. A 500 mb shortwave trough over the Ozarks moved northeast to the vicinity of the Ohio and Mississippi River confluence by mid-afternoon. A weak surface low pressure center moved northeast from southeast Missouri into south central Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were blown down onto roads from Griffin to the Wadesville area. One of the trees landed on Route 66.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south line of scattered thunderstorms intensified as it moved through the eastern half of central Indiana, producing wind damage across a few counties in east-central Indiana during the afternoon of May the 11th. These storms occurred ahead of a frontal boundary sweeping from west to east across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large trees were downed and a semi-truck was blown over due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of a complex of thunderstorms that moved through Illinois entered a moderately unstable and sheared environment across northern Indiana. Precipitable water values were running high, allowing for an increased threat of wet microbursts. Several of these occurred, producing localized damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated wind gusts to 65 mph with a wet microburst. Pea size hail was also observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported a large gazebo was blown over and damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a large and healthy eight inch diameter tree limb was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a large tree limb, approximately one foot in diameter, was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Harrison County emergency manager reported that a residence on Barren Avenue in Lanesville had 3 feet of water inside as a result of torrential rainfall and slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over County Road 275 East near Little Raccoon Creek due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be over the roadway near County Roads 200 West and 450 North from nearby Falls Branch Creek. This event occurred due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: WTHR reports that a lightning strike around 5:30 AM EDT Thursday is believed to be the cause of a house fire in the 5700 block of North Peppereel Way in McCordsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south line of scattered thunderstorms intensified as it moved through the eastern half of central Indiana, producing wind damage across a few counties in east-central Indiana during the afternoon of May the 11th. These storms occurred ahead of a frontal boundary sweeping from west to east across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree, 3 to 4 feet in diameter, was downed in a cemetery near the intersection of North Fort Wayne Road and 11th Street due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south line of scattered thunderstorms intensified as it moved through the eastern half of central Indiana, producing wind damage across a few counties in east-central Indiana during the afternoon of May the 11th. These storms occurred ahead of a frontal boundary sweeping from west to east across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down across the Farmland area due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. Trees were reported to be down on a residence, unoccupied vehicles, and down across a road blocking traffic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south line of scattered thunderstorms intensified as it moved through the eastern half of central Indiana, producing wind damage across a few counties in east-central Indiana during the afternoon of May the 11th. These storms occurred ahead of a frontal boundary sweeping from west to east across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were downed in and just south of Parker City due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south line of scattered thunderstorms intensified as it moved through the eastern half of central Indiana, producing wind damage across a few counties in east-central Indiana during the afternoon of May the 11th. These storms occurred ahead of a frontal boundary sweeping from west to east across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down across Highway 27 near State Route 28 due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed generally along and south of the Interstate 70 corridor during the afternoon through the early evening of the 30th of June. A couple of these storms produced both large and small hail as they moved southeast through central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lots of dime sized hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed generally along and south of the Interstate 70 corridor during the afternoon through the early evening of the 30th of June. A couple of these storms produced both large and small hail as they moved southeast through central Indiana.

After a dry first week to the month, strong to severe thunderstorms impacted central Indiana periodically throughout the remainder of June as the Ohio Valley remained in a generally unsettled weather pattern.  A humid air mass remained across central and|southern Indiana from the 11th through the 23rd.  A series of storms from the 12th through the 18th dropped 4 to more than 8 inches of rainfall in northern Indiana. A west-east line of storms developed across central Illinois and expanded eastward into central Indiana on the afternoon of June 18th, producing a few damaging wind reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple power poles were downed at the intersection of State Route 236 and County Road 500 North due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. Police and Fire departments responded. The wind and rain was strong, but no wind speed was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm developed along the Knox-Daviess county line and pushed eastward into the Washington area during the early afternoon of June 16th. By the late afternoon and early evening, an east-west line of thunderstorms had set up across the Washington area bringing a singular report of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some minor street flooding occurred in this location due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill tracked through the Ohio Valley bringing 3 to nearly 8 inches of rain on the 19th and early on the 20th to previously dry southern Indiana. This resulted in flooding and even flash flooding in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flooding had limited access to a property due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill tracked through the Ohio Valley bringing 3 to nearly 8 inches of rain on the 19th and early on the 20th to previously dry southern Indiana. This resulted in flooding and even flash flooding in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over State Route 450, east of Williams, due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill tracked through the Ohio Valley bringing 3 to nearly 8 inches of rain on the 19th and early on the 20th to previously dry southern Indiana.  This resulted in flooding and even flash flooding in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some minor street flooding was reported in this location due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill tracked through the Ohio Valley bringing 3 to nearly 8 inches of rain on the 19th and early on the 20th to previously dry southern Indiana.  This resulted in flooding and even flash flooding in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue was performed at a home surrounded by water near 4th and Thomas Street due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall. High water was also surrounding a trailer on Durbin Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed generally along and south of the Interstate 70 corridor during the afternoon through the early evening of the 30th of June. A couple of these storms produced both large and small hail as they moved southeast through central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail stones up to 1 inch in diameter were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last widespread rains of the month were the result of a developing low pressure area that moved through the state on the 26th and early on the 27th. Numerous flooding problems developed quickly across mainly northern sections of central Indiana. People were rescued from cars and homes were flooded in the Muncie area and other areas of east central Indiana. Much of the state along and north of Interstate 70 received 2 to 5 inches of rain. Two individuals perished near Noblesville when their automobile hit water on a road and crashed into a telephone pole.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of standing water was over the road in Sagamore Golf Club in Noblesville due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of thunderstorms brought heavy rain and some severe weather to central Indiana during the evenings of June 7th and June 8th. Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front the evening of June 7th. These brought rainfall of over 3 inches to portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs of unknown size were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts measured at 65 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of thunderstorms brought heavy rain and some severe weather to central Indiana during the evenings of June 7th and June 8th. Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front the evening of June 7th. These brought rainfall of over 3 inches to portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs equal to or greater than 2 inches were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of thunderstorms brought heavy rain and some severe weather to central Indiana during the evenings of June 7th and June 8th. Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front the evening of June 7th. These brought rainfall of over 3 inches to portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs, 1 to 2 inches around, were downed due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts near the intersection of 7th and Harrison Streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a dry first week to the month, strong to severe thunderstorms impacted central Indiana periodically throughout the remainder of June as the Ohio Valley remained in a generally unsettled weather pattern.  A humid air mass remained across central and|southern Indiana from the 11th through the 23rd.  A series of storms from the 12th through the 18th dropped 4 to more than 8 inches of rainfall in northern Indiana. A west-east line of storms developed across central Illinois and expanded eastward into central Indiana on the afternoon of June 18th, producing a few damaging wind reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs from a fairly healthy tree were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a dry first week to the month, strong to severe thunderstorms impacted central Indiana periodically throughout the remainder of June as the Ohio Valley remained in a generally unsettled weather pattern.  A humid air mass remained across central and|southern Indiana from the 11th through the 23rd.  A series of storms from the 12th through the 18th dropped 4 to more than 8 inches of rainfall in northern Indiana. A west-east line of storms developed across central Illinois and expanded eastward into central Indiana on the afternoon of June 18th, producing a few damaging wind reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed due to thunderstorm wind gusts observed at 49 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported numerous streets flooded in the city of Madison due to torrential and intense rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed a report of nickel size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado-warned storm pushed southeast across Patricksburg and near Freedom in Owen County on the evening of the 21st of June. Reports of large tree limbs being down came in as this storm moved across Owen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were down over county roads near and around Patricksburg and locations northwest of Spencer due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees were reported to be snapped in half and large trees uprooted due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. Many tree limbs, both large and small, were downed as well as an outhouse being blown off its' base.  The yard was completely covered in leaves, shingles, and limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Beginning on the 7th, numerous weather systems brought seemingly unending rains and at times torrential downpours to various portions of the state. The first heavy rains of the month occurred in portions of east central Illinois in addition to west central and northwest Indiana.  Rainfall of 2 to nearly 6 inches on the 7th caused flooding across portions of Warren, Fountain, and Vermillion counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported many roads with high water across northern Vermillion County due to thunderstorm heavy rainfall.

A few isolated thunderstorms developed across central Indiana during the afternoon of June 5th. One of these storms moved generally south-southeast into the Crothersville area causing some wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were knocked down in a subdivision near the intersection of Franklin and Southport Roads due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. A trampoline was blown over causing some minor damage to a house and a few vehicles.

Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water was flowing over a roadway near Meridian Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official relayed to the NWS that because of torrential rainfall, there were county roads flooded with high water flowing over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of trees down due to severe thunderstorm winds was received by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Beginning on the 7th, numerous weather systems brought seemingly unending rains and at times torrential downpours to various portions of the state. The first heavy rains of the month occurred in portions of east central Illinois in addition to west central and northwest Indiana.  Rainfall of 2 to nearly 6 inches on the 7th caused flooding across portions of Warren, Fountain, and Vermillion counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported high water along State Road 136, between Covington and Veedersburg, due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south oriented line of showers and thunderstorms developed across western Indiana as warm, moist air increased across the area during the early afternoon hours of May the 26th. As these storms pushed northeast into east-central Indiana during the middle to late afternoon, one moved over Henry County causing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One end of a pole barn was pushed in along with several tree limbs downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This event occurred near the intersection of County Roads 200 North and 500 East, east of Hillsboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-1 tornado, with winds estimated at 90 mph, briefly touched down near the intersection of Southeastern and Irvington Avenues. Significant garage damage occurred to two homes and one automobile was stacked on top of another. Numerous trees were downed as well. A power pole was downed as well as a gazebo that was picked up and tossed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The westbound lane of Highway 38 was underwater about half a mile west of Highway 13. Several inches of flowing water is also going over some driveways.  Heavy thunderstorm rainfall was the cause of the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stalled out frontal boundary draped across the Ohio Valley. The storms were very slow moving and produced locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The west fork of Four Mile Run came out of its banks and was flowing over Brookville Pike Road. A part of the road was washed away. In addition, trees were downed due to the flash flooding and a car was trapped in the water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stalled out frontal boundary draped across the Ohio Valley. The storms were very slow moving and produced locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water from earlier flash flooding covered parts of Brookville Pike Road through the night and into the early morning hours of July 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early morning thunderstorm complex rapidly developed over the Lower Ohio Valley ahead of a weak mid-level shortwave trough. The complex evolved into a broad zone of convection along and south of a stationary front that extended from central Missouri through central Illinois. Three-hour rainfall amounts were from one to two inches. The convection was focused along the nose of a low-level jet in a very moist air mass, with precipitable water values in the 2 to 2.25 inch range. Unidirectional wind flow from the surface to 500 mb resulted in little net movement of the convection. Although the best instability resided further south in the warm/moist sector, there was enough buoyancy in place to maintain convection. The front settled southward across western Kentucky by late afternoon, providing a focus for renewed convective complexes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rainfall amount of 2.25 inches was reported. Most of this rain fell within five hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early morning thunderstorm complex rapidly developed over the Lower Ohio Valley ahead of a weak mid-level shortwave trough. The complex evolved into a broad zone of convection along and south of a stationary front that extended from central Missouri through central Illinois. Three-hour rainfall amounts were from one to two inches. The convection was focused along the nose of a low-level jet in a very moist air mass, with precipitable water values in the 2 to 2.25 inch range. Unidirectional wind flow from the surface to 500 mb resulted in little net movement of the convection. Although the best instability resided further south in the warm/moist sector, there was enough buoyancy in place to maintain convection. The front settled southward across western Kentucky by late afternoon, providing a focus for renewed convective complexes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rainfall amount of 3.10 inches was reported. This rain fell in about five hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active June weather pattern continued through July, bringing fronts that moved across the region's river basins. The rainfall was sufficient to raise sections of the lower Ohio River slightly above flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Ohio River. Low-lying fields and woodlands near the river were underwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active June weather pattern continued through July, bringing fronts that moved across the region's river basins. The rainfall was sufficient to raise sections of the lower Ohio River slightly above flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Ohio River. Farm land and some main roads were flooded in places southwest and west of Mt. Vernon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals in July reached historic levels again, only this time in central and southern Indiana. For the state, July 2015 was the 7th wettest July of record and the wettest since the record wet July of 1992. July???s rainfall prolonged the widespread river flooding that began in June and caused higher flooding in southern Indiana. Flooding along the Wabash River in western Indiana that began in mid June continued through most of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding continued along the Wabash River from June through most of July. At the Mount Carmel river gage, the river crested at 25.8 feet in late June. Flood stage is 19 feet. Extensive lowland flooding occurred, inundating hundreds of acres of cropland. Numerous local river roads were flooded. Some mobile homes were moved out of the flood plain. Access to local camp sites and river cabins was blocked, but there was minimal impact to commercial activities. Some nearby oil fields were inaccessible.

Flooding along the Wabash River in western Indiana that began in mid June continued through most of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding continued along the Wabash River from June through most of July. Low-lying fields, woodlands, and some oil wells were flooded in the flood plain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding continued along the Patoka River from June into early July. Low-lying fields and woodlands near the river were inundated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals in July reached historic levels again, only this time in central and southern Indiana. For the state, July 2015 was the 7th wettest July of record and the wettest since the record wet July of 1992. July???s rainfall prolonged the widespread river flooding that began in June and caused higher flooding in southern Indiana. Flooding along the Wabash River in western Indiana that began in mid June continued through most of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding continued along the White River from June through most of July. Because it was agricultural season, extensive flooding of river bottomlands caused significant crop damage. High water surrounded any residents in river cabins. Several streets and back roads were flooded and impassable. Oil fields were flooded. Flood gates were installed at Hazleton. A softball field was underwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: From the city of Evansville east along the Ohio River, afternoon temperatures in the lower to mid 90's combined with oppressive humidity levels to create heat indices near 105 degrees. The peak heat index was 105 at Evansville.  A cold front over southwest Indiana was preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of 3/4 inch diameter hail was received by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals in July reached historic levels again, only this time in central and southern Indiana. For the state, July 2015 was the 7th wettest July of record and the wettest since the record wet July of 1992. July???s rainfall prolonged the widespread river flooding that began in June and caused higher flooding in southern Indiana. Flooding along the Wabash River in western Indiana that began in mid June continued through most of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding continued along the White River from June through most of July. Low-lying woods and fields near the river were inundated. State Route 257 was flooded. Numerous Pike County roads were flooded, including County Roads 750N, 600N, and 1000E east of State Route 57. West of State Route 57, County Roads 250W, 400W, 675N, 700N, 1000W, 900W, 700W, and 775W were flooded. Low agricultural lands and low oil fields were inundated. Because it was agricultural season, significant crop damage occurred. River cabins were isolated by high water.

Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down in this location due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This report was received via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled front combined with a very moist air mass to produce slow moving thunderstorms across the area July 1st through July 3rd. Recent heavy rain across the area had already saturated the ground and as a result, flash flooding occurred more quickly. The hardest hit areas included Orange county and parts of Dubois and Crawford counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dubois County emergency manager reported that Highway 164 was flooded and impassable near Patoka Lake. A very localized thunderstorm produced between 3 and 5 inches of rain in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled front combined with a very moist air mass to produce slow moving thunderstorms across the area July 1st through July 3rd. Recent heavy rain across the area had already saturated the ground and as a result, flash flooding occurred more quickly. The hardest hit areas included Orange county and parts of Dubois and Crawford counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Crawford County official reported that a family was evacuated and rescued due to high water and flash flooding in Taswell. The dispatcher also reported that numerous roads throughout the county were closed and impassable because of flash flooding. Between 3 and 5 inches of rain quickly fell in the area from a localized slow moving thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. In addition, due to the very wet antecedent conditions, flash flooding occurred on occasion, resulting in closed and impassable roads, water rescues and significant property damage. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of a flooded road in Charlestown. Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell from several rounds of severe thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 1 inch diameter hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few branches, up to 1.5 inches thick and several feet long, were downed in this location.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Indiana Department of Homeland Security called reporting trees down, power lines down, and damage to homes from around 10th and Tibbs Streets to Meridian Street and Thompson Road due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening complex of thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall as it moved across Indiana during the early morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was covering multiple roads in Brookville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms associated with an upper level disturbance moved southeast through the Ohio Valley late on the evening of July 13th and into the early morning hours of July 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were downed onto State Route 262.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding across portions of northwest Indiana late on July 8th into July 9th.  A trained spotter measured 3.32 inches of rain in Morocco, Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County Road 700W was flooded and closed between Division Street and 100S.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small but intense complex of severe thunderstorms developed north of the area but quickly moved into southern Indiana during the evening hours of July 17th. Widespread damaging wind gusts estimated between 55 and 60 mph occurred, resulting in toppled trees and power lines. The Madison, Indiana area was particularly hit hard with damaging winds as well as flash flooding given the very wet conditions in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of flash flooding of roadways near the West Fork Fourteenmile Creek in Clark County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with an upper level disturbance pushed down into the Ohio Valley during the mid day hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds knocked a large tree limb down onto West 8th Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and moist air mass overspread the region in the wake of a warm front that had lifted through the area. This allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop across the Ohio Valley through the afternoon hours. The storms continued into the evening hours, resulting in localized flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong to severe quasi-linear convective system dropped southeast out of Wisconsin and intensified as it moved across Lake Michigan. This led to sporadic wind damage, mainly in southwest lower Michigan and northern Indiana, as well as localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: House struck by lightning in 11000 block of Leesburg Road. Caused a delayed fire. The home was a total loss with damages estimated at least $75,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding across portions of northwest Indiana late on July 8th into July 9th.  A trained spotter measured 3.32 inches of rain in Morocco, Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A foot of flowing water was reported on Route 55 near 650N.  A car was pushed off the road into a field.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Indiana during the early morning hours July 12th and slowly tracked into southern Indiana shortly before dawn. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain fell in a 1 to 2 hour time frame, resulting in flash flooding across parts of the area. The system was also accompanied by an intense amount of lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that lightning struck the Sulphur Pentecostal Church. According to the Crawford County emergency manager, the church was destroyed and determined to be a total loss.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: July began on a dry note for much of Indiana north of Indianapolis. Locally heavy rains of 1 to more than 4 inches fell in southern Indiana from late on June 30th through July 3rd.  A 5.50 rainfall report came in from Shelby County, which is the area that saw flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ankle deep water was observed in a basement of a home in Shelbyville due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall. This was reported by CBS4.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: July began on a dry note for much of Indiana north of Indianapolis. Locally heavy rains of 1 to more than 4 inches fell in southern Indiana from late on June 30th through July 3rd. Flash flooding occurred across portions of Martin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported across several roads in southern Martin County, including portions of Route 231, due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A particularly wet and stormy pattern began on the 7th and continued through the 20th. Rains returned with a vengeance to portions of central Indiana during the afternoon of the 7th. The Plainfield area, immediately west of the Indianapolis airport, received up to 6 inches of rain in less than 6 hours. Severe local flooding occurred as a result of this rainfall. The Indianapolis airport received 4.43 inches of rain, a record for the date and the highest daily total since Labor Day 2003.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant, widespread street flooding occurred in northwest Muncie due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

The Indianapolis airport received 4.43 inches of rain, a record for the date and the highest daily total since Labor Day 2003.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two cars were stranded in high water at the intersection of Kentucky and Belmont Avenues due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall. Police had to block traffic.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over the road at the intersection of State Route 9 and County Road 350 South.  This was reported by CBS4.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a hot and unstable atmosphere across central Indiana during the afternoon and early evening of July 17th. The storms produced 2 tornadoes in southeast Tippecanoe County along with some hail and strong winds elsewhere. The storms also brought very heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding in some areas, including parts of the Indianapolis Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed along Route 3 due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

Numerous trees, west of the affected residence, had tops sheared off or were downed completely and a garage at the residence was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Indiana during the early morning hours July 12th and slowly tracked into southern Indiana shortly before dawn. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain fell in a 1 to 2 hour time frame, resulting in flash flooding across parts of the area. The system was also accompanied by an intense amount of lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report was received of high water in parts of Austin. An apartment building was partially flooded and rainfall amounts varied from 1 to locally 3 inches across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Indiana during the early morning hours July 12th and slowly tracked into southern Indiana shortly before dawn. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain fell in a 1 to 2 hour time frame, resulting in flash flooding across parts of the area. The system was also accompanied by an intense amount of lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report was received of high water flooding parts of Castlewood Drive. Between 2 and 3 inches fell within 2 hours across much of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. In addition, due to the very wet antecedent conditions, flash flooding occurred on occasion, resulting in closed and impassable roads, water rescues and significant property damage. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of 5 to 10 water rescues that occurred in Madison as a result of flash flooding. Approximately 5,000 residences and businesses lost power as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of a mud slide at Hanover Hill due to flash flooding. Between 3 and 5 inches of rain fell in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jefferson County emergency manager reported multiple trees fell down in the county due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A particularly wet and stormy pattern began on the 7th and continued through the 20th. Rains returned with a vengeance to portions of central Indiana during the afternoon of the 7th. The Plainfield area, immediately west of the Indianapolis airport, received up to 6 inches of rain in less than 6 hours. Severe local flooding occurred as a result of this rainfall. The Indianapolis airport received 4.43 inches of rain, a record for the date and the highest daily total since Labor Day 2003.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water, estimated at 8 to 10 inches deep, was covering the road at the intersection of Highfall and Shadowlawn Avenues. No barricades were in place but police were aware of the flooding. Multiple other locations inside and outside the city limits also have flooding.

The Indianapolis airport received 4.43 inches of rain, a record for the date and the highest daily total since Labor Day 2003.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several houses surrounded by water on County Road 350 due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rainfall over the past 4 hours has created flash flooding resulting in swiftly moving water. Rain is continuing to fall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across central Indiana during the early morning of July 12, bringing heavy rain, flooding, and a tornado to the area. Some locations received over 5 inches of rain in just 3 hours. Numerous homes were flooded and roads closed due to high water. The tornado brought down many trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported trees down near Princes Lake, both in Johnson and Brown counties, due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a hot and unstable atmosphere across central Indiana during the afternoon and early evening of July 17th. The storms produced 2 tornadoes in southeast Tippecanoe County along with some hail and strong winds elsewhere. The storms also brought very heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding in some areas, including parts of the Indianapolis Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over a curb and taking up most of the northbound lane in the 600 block of Virginia Avenue in Fountain Square due to moderate to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a hot and unstable atmosphere across central Indiana during the afternoon and early evening of July 17th. The storms produced 2 tornadoes in southeast Tippecanoe County along with some hail and strong winds elsewhere. The storms also brought very heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding in some areas, including parts of the Indianapolis Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 50 is flooded due to moderate to heavy rainfall, but traffic is able to get through.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front from the northwest interacted with a warm and very moist air mass during the afternoon hours of July 7th. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed, some of which produced flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dubois County emergency manager reported some roads across the county were flooded due to high water. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell from slow moving thunderstorms, on top of already saturated ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front from the northwest interacted with a warm and very moist air mass during the afternoon hours of July 7th. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed, some of which produced flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dubois County emergency manager reported flooded roads in the area from excessive rainfall. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell from slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front from the northwest interacted with a warm and very moist air mass during the afternoon hours of July 7th. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed, some of which produced flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An Orange County law enforcement official reported that Highway 150 between French Lick and Paoli was flooded in spots. Around 2 inches of rain fell in the area from slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front from the northwest interacted with a warm and very moist air mass during the afternoon hours of July 7th. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed, some of which produced flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported that SR56 west of Paoli was closed due to high water flowing over it. Around 2 inches of rain fell from slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front from the northwest interacted with a warm and very moist air mass during the afternoon hours of July 7th. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed, some of which produced flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dubois County emergency manager reported flooded roads in the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report of flooded and impassable side streets was received across pars of Jeffersonville. Rainfall amounts across southern Clark County varied from 3 to locally 4 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report was received of numerous street flooding due to excessive rainfall and intense rain rates. Much of Clark County received 3 to locally 4 inches in a span of 60 to 90 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across central Indiana during the early morning of July 12, bringing heavy rain, flooding, and a tornado to the area. Some locations received over 5 inches of rain in just 3 hours. Numerous homes were flooded and roads closed due to high water. The tornado brought down many trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A sporadic path of trees were downed from State Route 135, just southwest of Samaria, southeast to near Princes Lakes. Corn stalks and a few trees in a field along County Road 450 West, south of County Road 525 South, were laid down in multiple directions. The maximum width of damage was found in this area. Several homes sustained property damage to trees falling on them in a neighborhood along County Road 750 South and on the northwest side of Princes Lakes.||Radar analysis combined with the survey information is suggestive that areas of straight line downburst winds may have occurred within the damage path as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed around the county because of flooding due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall. Also, White Lick Creek was about a foot out of its banks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five roads were washed out with numerous roads flooded county-wide due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last of the string of storms occurred during the evening of the 20th into the early morning of the 21st. A thunderstorm developed over downtown Indianapolis and dumped up to 3 inches of rain. Brief significant local flooding followed in downtown Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stuck in high water near the intersection of 25th Street and Hillside Avenue due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Clark County law enforcement official reported that a water rescue was performed near the intersection of Henryville-Otisco and Pfister roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Clark County emergency manager along with several media outlets reported the drowning of a 67 year old male after he reportedly drove through a flooded roadway. Several inches of rain had fallen during the previous night, flooding a portion of Tunnel Mill Road. His vehicle was found several hours later and a search team discovered his body later that evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last of the string of storms occurred during the evening of the 20th into the early morning of the 21st. A thunderstorm developed over downtown Indianapolis and dumped up to 3 inches of rain. Brief significant local flooding followed in downtown Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be in the hallways at the Raleigh apartments near the intersection of Pennsylvania and 13th Streets due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The longest dry spell for almost the entire state since early June began on the 21st and lasted until the afternoon of the 26th. After the Brickyard 400 ended, storms developed in central Indiana during the late afternoon of the 26th. Heavy rains of 1 to more than 5 inches fell in the Indianapolis metro area and areas immediately northwest and southeast of downtown Indianapolis. The heaviest rainfall occurred in the northeast portion of Indianapolis where brief severe local flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported along Kessler Boulevard due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A concrete plant had it's roof blown off due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. The building's bay doors were open at the time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down north of Frankfort due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust was observed in this location. No damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A driver was injured by a tree falling due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This event was reported by WTHR.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The PNC Bank sign at the intersection of Ford and Oak Streets was damaged due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices peaked around 110 degrees on two consecutive afternoons. The maximum observed heat index at the Evansville airport was 110 degrees on the 29th. Emergency room doctors at a local hospital reported a sharp increase in heat-related illnesses, such as heat cramps and heat strokes. However, no exact numbers were available. The heat caused some interruptions of outdoor projects. Roofing repairs at the Warrick County courthouse were delayed. A 500 mb high over the southern Plains built slowly east and northeast into the Mid-Mississippi Valley. At the surface, weak high pressure over the Tennessee Valley produced a persistent southwest wind flow.

Afternoon temperatures in the lower to mid 90's combined with oppressive humidity levels to create heat indices around 105 degrees. The observed peak heat index reading at Evansville was 105. A homeless shelter in Evansville expanded its operations for the duration of the heat wave. Hot southwest winds preceded a cold front that extended from the Upper Mississippi Valley to the central Plains.

A small but intense complex of severe thunderstorms developed north of the area but quickly moved into southern Indiana during the evening hours of July 17th. Widespread damaging wind gusts estimated between 55 and 60 mph occurred, resulting in toppled trees and power lines. The Madison, Indiana area was particularly hit hard with damaging winds as well as flash flooding given the very wet conditions in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported trees and power lines down across the area due to severe thunderstorm winds.

The Madison, Indiana area was particularly hit hard with damaging winds as well as flash flooding given the very wet conditions in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed a report that severe thunderstorm winds resulted in a tree falling on a carport in Clarksville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small but intense complex of severe thunderstorms developed north of the area but quickly moved into southern Indiana during the evening hours of July 17th. Widespread damaging wind gusts estimated between 55 and 60 mph occurred, resulting in toppled trees and power lines. The Madison, Indiana area was particularly hit hard with damaging winds as well as flash flooding given the very wet conditions in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report was received of high water over the intersection of Highway 450W and Ten Cent Road. Between 2 and 2.5 inches of rain fell in the area on top of very saturated grounds from recent heavy rainfall events.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was down across a car at Oak and Sycamore Streets due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding across portions of east central Illinois.  An observer near Kentland, Indiana measured 3.33 inches of rain in just two hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Newton County Sheriff reported that there was flooding across much of southern Newton County, mainly south of the Iroquois River, including Kentland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled front combined with a very moist air mass to produce slow moving thunderstorms across the area July 1st through July 3rd. Recent heavy rain across the area had already saturated the ground and as a result, flash flooding occurred more quickly. The hardest hit areas included Orange county and parts of Dubois and Crawford counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Crawford County dispatcher reported that flash flooding and high water closed two roads, SR 164 at SR 145 and SR 145 at Deich Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, including a few supercells, moved across northwest Indiana producing large hail and at least one brief tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Baseball size hail was reported on the 3900 Block of Hohman Avenue.  Golfball size hail was reported at Indianapolis Boulevard and Michigan Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, including a few supercells, moved across northwest Indiana producing large hail and at least one brief tornado.
Scattered thunderstorms, including a few supercells, moved across northwest Indiana producing large hail and at least one brief tornado.
Scattered thunderstorms, including a few supercells, moved across northwest Indiana producing large hail and at least one brief tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A short lived tornado touched down and was on the ground for around a minute.  The tornado occurred in an open area with no damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and moist air mass overspread the region in the wake of a warm front that had lifted through the area. This allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop across the Ohio Valley through the afternoon hours. The storms continued into the evening hours, resulting in localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over a bridge on W County Road 200 S.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a hot and unstable atmosphere across central Indiana during the afternoon and early evening of July 17th. The storms produced 2 tornadoes in southeast Tippecanoe County along with some hail and strong winds elsewhere. The storms also brought very heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding in some areas, including parts of the Indianapolis Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS survey revealed EF1 damage with approximately 97 mph winds in the southeast portion of Tippecanoe County, south of the intersection of Highway 52 and County Road 900 South. Observed damage included a collapsed garage, downed trees, and at least one home with vinyl siding removed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell thunderstorm produced a brief EF0 tornado about 18 miles west of Lafayette or about 2.5 miles southeast of Pine Village in Northern Warren County. The tornado was observed by a trained spotter briefly touching down in a corn field, producing no damage other than to the crops at the touchdown point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. In addition, due to the very wet antecedent conditions, flash flooding occurred on occasion, resulting in closed and impassable roads, water rescues and significant property damage. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Jefferson County law enforcement official reported trees down across much of the county due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were down, with several on vehicles, due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. Significant tree damage was reported at Crawfordsville Road and Lynhurst Drive. Damage was also reported from Gerrard and 21st Streets.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS survey revealed EF1 damage with 90 mph winds in the northeast tip of the Heritage Lake area. Tornado damage was embedded in a broad area of downburst damage across northeast Putnam County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak shortwave trough moving through upper Michigan combined with retreating outflow boundary from morning/early afternoon storms, which moved through northern Indiana/northwest Ohio, spurned new storm development from southern Wisconsin southeast through northeast Illinois by later afternoon. Storms were initially sub-severe and disorganized, but two main bowing segments, one along and north of the Interstate 80/90 corridor and another along the US-30 corridor, developed as cold pool strengthened, causing widespread damaging winds and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down on North Wozniak Road, just south of County Road 400 North.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong to severe quasi-linear convective system dropped southeast out of Wisconsin and intensified as it moved across Lake Michigan. This led to sporadic wind damage, mainly in southwest lower Michigan and northern Indiana, as well as localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding of creeks reported in Huntertown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a hot and unstable atmosphere across central Indiana during the afternoon and early evening of July 17th. The storms produced 2 tornadoes in southeast Tippecanoe County along with some hail and strong winds elsewhere. The storms also brought very heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding in some areas, including parts of the Indianapolis Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This report was relayed via amateur radio from a social media webpage.

The storms also brought very heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding in some areas, including parts of the Indianapolis Metro Area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power poles were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.

A northward retreating outflow boundary from morning thunderstorms and eastward migration of upstream instability allowed for convection to fire later in the evening as the cap eroded and an upstream upper level trough approached the region. Storms initially produced isolated hail and wind damage, however heavy rainfall and flash flooding quickly became the primary threat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of water over roads across Whitley County, including at State Road 9 and County Road 400 South.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak shortwave trough moving through upper Michigan combined with retreating outflow boundary from morning/early afternoon storms, which moved through northern Indiana/northwest Ohio, spurned new storm development from southern Wisconsin southeast through northeast Illinois by later afternoon. Storms were initially sub-severe and disorganized, but two main bowing segments, one along and north of the Interstate 80/90 corridor and another along the US-30 corridor, developed as cold pool strengthened, causing widespread damaging winds and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four animal shelters destroyed and several limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 65 mph thunderstorm wind gust was measured in this location. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across central Indiana during the early morning of July 12, bringing heavy rain, flooding, and a tornado to the area. Some locations received over 5 inches of rain in just 3 hours. Numerous homes were flooded and roads closed due to high water. The tornado brought down many trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescues and home evacuations occurred in Mooresville because of flash flooding due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall. This report was relay via broadcast media from Twitter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last of the string of storms occurred during the evening of the 20th into the early morning of the 21st. A thunderstorm developed over downtown Indianapolis and dumped up to 3 inches of rain. Brief significant local flooding followed in downtown Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of 16th Street was flooded between the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and Downtown Indianapolis due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall. This report was relayed by a WISH-TV meteorologist.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor tree limbs were downed due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts.
