EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms dropped across northwestern Indiana producing severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerlines were blown down in Portage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms dropped across northwestern Indiana producing severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerlines were blown down across portions of Valparaiso.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed over northwest Indiana producing hail.
A few thunderstorms developed over northwest Indiana producing hail.
Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported trees and some large limbs down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported roughly a half dozen trees uprooted in the same direction. A wall was removed from a chicken coop.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported trees and tree limbs down, with some into roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported sporadic trees being blown down onto the road between Otter Lake and Crooked Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported two trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported that a building, known as the Round Barn, sustained damage at the Fulton County museum. Review of the photos indicates that a microburst likely occurred in an open area with the wind traveling to a double barn door that was pushed in and the roof then compromised. Few if any other adjacent damage indicators were impacted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary surface boundary across the region combined with an upper level disturbance coming in from the west produced a round of scattered strong to severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana. The main hazard was damaging winds which brought down trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Harrison County law enforcement official reported trees down on Dixie Road near Mauckport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary surface boundary across the region combined with an upper level disturbance coming in from the west produced a round of scattered strong to severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana. The main hazard was damaging winds which brought down trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Harrison County law enforcement official reported trees down along Elizabeth - New Middletown Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe thunderstorms developed across southern Indiana during the afternoon and evening hours August 15th as an upper level system passed through in the presence of a warm and moist air mass.  One particular storm moved through Dubois County and produced damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator reported that severe thunderstorm winds brought down a few trees and power poles in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved into northern Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Roughly 1000 J/Kg of surface based CAPE was available with a very weak flow aloft (10 to 20 knots). Thunderstorms slowly developed across the area and given the weak flow moved very slowly. Isolated wind damage and flooding was reported from a few storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm remained over Lake Wawasee for nearly 90 minutes, dropping torrential rainfall. Rainfall totals peak out at just over 5 inches, on the northeast side of the lake. Flooding occurred on State Route 13, near the South Shore Golf Course, where high water signs had to be posted for several hours. Flooding was minimized across the area as a result of the majority of the rain likely falling into the lake. Rainfall amounts quickly diminished a few miles outside of this main area with the National Weather Service office picking up 1.86 inches of rain in the same amount of time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe storms on the afternoon of the 3rd produced large hail across portions of Delaware and Randolph Counties.  Golf ball size hail occurred southeast of Muncie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail fell for 5 to 10 minutes and covered the ground in patches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe storms on the afternoon of the 3rd produced large hail across portions of Delaware and Randolph Counties.  Golf ball size hail occurred southeast of Muncie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was seen on Facebook.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement out on a call observed the hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved into northern Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Roughly 1000 J/Kg of surface based CAPE was available with a very weak flow aloft (10 to 20 knots). Thunderstorms slowly developed across the area and given the weak flow moved very slowly. Isolated wind damage and flooding was reported from a few storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off duty reported a tree was uprooted in her yard, with high water into her garage. Tree was uprooted to the east. Result of an isolated wet microburst.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved into northern Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Roughly 1000 J/Kg of surface based CAPE was available with a very weak flow aloft (10 to 20 knots). Thunderstorms slowly developed across the area and given the weak flow moved very slowly. Isolated wind damage and flooding was reported from a few storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A survey of the area around Waco Drive on the southwest side of Lake Wawasee revealed several tree limbs were blown down as a result of a wet microburst from a stationary storm over the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept across eastern Indiana into northwestern Ohio during the afternoon hours. Scattered thunderstorms developed in eastern portion of Indiana, intensifying as they moved east into Ohio. While most remained below severe limits, an increasingly unstable environment and 35 knots of low level shear set the stage for a few storms to produce damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported two to three foot diameter tree limbs were blown down as well as part of a barn roof was blown off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Sunny skies ahead of a strong cold front allowed for the mixing of stronger winds aloft to the ground. While wind gusts only peaked out at between 30 and 40 mph, they were sufficient to cause damage to a tree in South Bend which fell onto several people in bleachers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree branch was blown down by gusty winds onto a bleacher at a soccer game in Studebaker Park. Five people of varying ages, including a ten month old girl were injured. The ten month old child died as a result of her injuries on August 5th. A ten year old child suffered severe head trauma with others suffering various cuts and bruises.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed along a corridor from southern Illinois across northwest Kentucky and southwest Indiana. The storms developed along and just ahead of a weak surface boundary as it drifted southward into a very unstable air mass over the Lower Ohio Valley. Isolated wind damage accompanied the strongest storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two large trees were blown down across South County Road 800 West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front extended eastward from a low pressure center over central Missouri. Small clusters of thunderstorms along the warm front produced isolated strong wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were blown down and tents were blown around. An off-duty meteorologist estimated winds gusted to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain bands associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Bill produced isolated strong winds and very heavy rain. The convective character of the bands increased during the afternoon due to short intervals of sunshine that destabilized the atmosphere. The surface low pressure center that constituted the remnants of Bill was located over the extreme southeast corner of Missouri during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down near Highway 57 just west of the Interstate 69 interchange.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed as a low pressure center tracked east along a stationary front which was draped across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over the road at the 5200 block of Abington Pike, which closed the road. High water signs were placed elsewhere throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of June 8th producing primarily large hail, some up to the size of golf balls.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail fell across Schererville causing damage to vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of June 8th producing primarily large hail, some up to the size of golf balls.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around nine inches of standing water was reported at County Road N 725 W and U.S. 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of June 8th producing primarily large hail, some up to the size of golf balls.

Isolated thunderstorms formed along an old thunderstorm outflow boundary over southern Illinois and western Kentucky. The storms congealed into a mass of heavy rain as they propagated east across southwest Indiana in the evening. Late at night, another mesoscale convective system increased in size as it moved southeast across southwest Indiana. This second system produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor street flooding was reported. A spotter reported 1.3 inches of rain in one hour on the southeast side of Evansville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed along an old thunderstorm outflow boundary over southern Illinois and western Kentucky. The storms congealed into a mass of heavy rain as they propagated east across southwest Indiana in the evening. Late at night, another mesoscale convective system increased in size as it moved southeast across southwest Indiana. This second system produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over the road at the intersection of Old Highway 231 and County Road 1000N, at the east fork of Little Pigeon Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms formed along a weakening convective outflow boundary as it moved southeast across the Lower Ohio Valley. Locally heavy rainfall occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 1.5 inches of rain in 40 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a surface low pressure system and were enhanced by energy from an upper level shortwave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree knocked down on Thuermer Hollow Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a surface low pressure system and were enhanced by energy from an upper level shortwave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple large tree branches were downed near the New Marion Volunteer Fire Department.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of June 8th producing primarily large hail, some up to the size of golf balls.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree branches were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread river flooding occurred as a result of several heavy rain events in June. The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill on the 19th were responsible for widespread heavy rain that drove the smaller rivers above flood stage. Flooding of the White and Wabash Rivers was due to excessive rainfall in the upper portions of both river basins. Both Illinois and Indiana recorded their wettest Junes on record. June was also in the top five wettest months on record for both states.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred on the Wabash River. At the Mount Carmel river gage, the river crested at 25.8 feet on the 29th. Flood stage is 19 feet. Extensive lowland flooding occurred. Numerous local river roads were flooded. Some mobile homes were moved out of the flood plain. Access to local camp sites and river cabins was blocked, but there was minimal impact to commercial activities. Some nearby oil fields were inaccessible.  The flooding continued into July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread river flooding occurred as a result of several heavy rain events in June. The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill on the 19th were responsible for widespread heavy rain that drove the smaller rivers above flood stage. Flooding of the White and Wabash Rivers was due to excessive rainfall in the upper portions of both river basins. Both Illinois and Indiana recorded their wettest Junes on record. June was also in the top five wettest months on record for both states.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River. Low-lying woods and fields near the river were inundated. State Route 257 was flooded. Numerous Pike County roads were flooded, including County Roads 750N, 600N, and 1000E east of State Route 57. West of State Route 57, County Roads 250W, 400W, 675N, 700N, 1000W, 900W, 700W, and 775W were flooded. Low agricultural lands and low oil fields were inundated. The flooding continued into July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and early evening, multiple storms produced severe hail and very heavy rainfall along the I-80 corridor.

Widespread river flooding occurred as a result of several heavy rain events in June. The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill on the 19th were responsible for widespread heavy rain that drove the smaller rivers above flood stage. Flooding of the White and Wabash Rivers was due to excessive rainfall in the upper portions of both river basins. Both Illinois and Indiana recorded their wettest Junes on record. June was also in the top five wettest months on record for both states.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River. Low-lying woods and fields near the river were inundated. High water affected any residents in Pottsville river cabins. A few streets were flooded and impassable. Oil stripped fields were flooded. Flood gates were installed at Hazleton. A softball field was underwater. The flooding continued into July.

June was also in the top five wettest months on record for both states.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Wabash River. Low-lying fields, woodlands, and some oil wells were flooded in the flood plain. The flooding continued into July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An 18-year-old Covington man is dead after being swept through the Coal Creek low head dam. According to Indiana Conservation Officers, all area waterways are flooded and dangerous following the recent rain. Officers said they have been responding to people swept away all week due to young people swimming or floating the creeks in an inner tube.||Conservation officers warn that people drown in flooded waterways because they underestimate the relentless power of moving water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 18-year-old Covington man is dead after being swept through the Coal Creek low head dam Saturday, July 13th. Indiana Conservation Officers were called to the area just after 7:00 PM EDT after Fountain County Dispatch received a report of a man that had been swept through the Coal Creek low head dam in Stringtown. Multiple agencies responded to the scene to begin rescue efforts.  At approximately 9:00 PM EDT, Covington Fire personnel found the body of an 18-year-old Covington resident about a mile and a half downstream.  He was pronounced dead at the scene by the Fountain County Coroner???s Office.  According to Indiana Conservation Officers, all area waterways are flooded and dangerous following the recent rain. Officers said they have been responding to people swept away all week due to young people swimming or floating the creeks in an inner tube.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and early evening, multiple storms produced severe hail and very heavy rainfall along the I-80 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to quarter size hail was reported near State Routes 49 and 2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and early evening, multiple storms produced severe hail and very heavy rainfall along the I-80 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down in Lowell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain bands associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Bill produced isolated strong winds and very heavy rain. The convective character of the bands increased during the afternoon due to short intervals of sunshine that destabilized the atmosphere. The surface low pressure center that constituted the remnants of Bill was located over the extreme southeast corner of Missouri during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several highway exits throughout the city of Evansville were flooded. A few rural roadways outside the city were shut down. Creeks and ditches were flowing out of their banks. The daily rainfall total for the 19th at the Evansville airport was 3.65 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms persisted well into the night ahead of a low-amplitude mid-level shortwave trough. These storms moved eastward through a corridor of very moist air, with precipitable water values approaching two inches. The convection was near and south of a surface front that extended from Iowa to southern Ohio. A few storms produced strong gusty winds and isolated large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media user posted a photo of the hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms persisted well into the night ahead of a low-amplitude mid-level shortwave trough. These storms moved eastward through a corridor of very moist air, with precipitable water values approaching two inches. The convection was near and south of a surface front that extended from Iowa to southern Ohio. A few storms produced strong gusty winds and isolated large hail.

Clusters of thunderstorms persisted well into the night ahead of a low-amplitude mid-level shortwave trough. These storms moved eastward through a corridor of very moist air, with precipitable water values approaching two inches. The convection was near and south of a surface front that extended from Iowa to southern Ohio. A few storms produced strong gusty winds and isolated large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Construction signs were blown down at the intersection of U.S. Highway 41 and Indiana Highway 68.
